response:
The clinical presentation is characteristic of a left-sided Brown-Séquard syndrome (hemicord lesion). This is evidenced by ipsilateral (left-sided) upper motor neuron signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia, upgoing plantar response) and ipsilateral loss of dorsal column sensation (vibration/proprioception), combined with contralateral (right-sided) loss of spinothalamic sensation (pinprick). The presence of weakness in the left wrist extensors (C6/C7 myotome) localises the lesion to the cervical level.

lesion_locations = ["Left Cervical Spinal Cord"]
